newsitem.title: REPUBLIC OF IRELAND: Irish govt seeks election timing advice - newspaper.
newsitem.headline: Irish govt seeks election timing advice - newspaper.

text.p: The Irish government has taken formal advice on the timing of a general election, a constitutional referendum and a possible presidential election in 1997, the Irish Times reported on Monday.

The government has been advised that the present Parliament must be dissolved not later than December 13, 1997, a recent letter to the secretary to the government, Frank Murray, from the department of the environment said, the Irish Times report said.
It said the polling day for the next general election could, therefore, be as late as mid-January, 1998.
Most observers in parliament currently believe that the general election will be held in May/June.
